body: @mistercrunch I would suggest using `DAG.catch_up` (or `DAG.allow_catch_up`) (we are reasoning from the perspective DAG not from the scheduler). In the config section I would suggest to use `catch_up_by_default` as it already resides under the scheduler section. Bit semantic, but it made it easier in my mind.

Hey great work on this, but at the moment it does not seem very clean. It seems to contain multiple functional changes and it misses documentation. As running as another user has security implications I would expect some thoughts on the approach. 

Maybe it is smart to split up between the cgroups and impersonation?

That being said, I'm really excited that this is getting traction.
There are dozen's of saml providers and okta is just one of them... so instead of `okta_auth` there should be `saml_auth`, using that user's should be able to configure any saml provider.

Does any one know why [VariableView](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/1940/files#diff-948e87b4f8f644b3ad8c7950958df033L2166) which is under `Admin` category opened to data profiling? 

cc - @mistercrunch @r39132 @artwr @bolkedebruin @criccomini

> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io?src=pr). Last update [2306892...db2572a](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/compare/23068924c09d6cebb0af6151b1950197ac16e67b...db2572a3914ef0c857b3b059e7c40062e1cd0d70?src=pr)

@bolkedebruin 
There were a lot of merge conflicts rebasing the changes on master so this might be a bit tricky to split into two PRs though I agree with you in principle. Would be very happy filling in any missing gaps in the PR though.

As for documentation there is this:
```
Airflow has the ability to impersonate a unix user while running task
 instances based on the task's ``run_as_user`` parameter, which takes a user's name.
 
 *NOTE* For impersonations to work, Airflow must be run with `sudo` as subtasks are run
 with `sudo -u` and permissions of files are changed. Furthermore, the unix user needs to
 exist on the worker.
 
 Subtasks with impersonation will still log to the same folder, except that the files they
 log to will have permissions changed such that only the unix user can write to it.
 
 *Default impersonation* To prevent tasks that don't use impersonation to be run with `sudo` privileges,
 you can set the `default_impersonation` config in `core` which sets a default user impersonate
 if `run_as_user` is not set.
```
But I can add any pieces you think are missing, or more verbosity/detail.

@bolkedebruin I agree that it'd be nice to have these 2 distinct features as 2 PRs, but having overseen the work here they fit very nicely together since they hook in at the same spot (wrapping the subprocess execution) and have common requirements (elevating the permissions of the user running the main process)

It'd be quite a surgery to cut this and I feel like it'd be more risky. Keep in mind this has been running for months in production at Airbnb, so cutting it in pieces brings in more risks across the board then the simpler one-at-a-time surgery (as opposed to 2 surgeries).
When testing, did you actually experience a 500 error, and the code worked properly?

@rogaha an easy solution is to have two tasks, one dependent on the other, and have the dependent task push the XCom and the first task check for it.
@jlowin I didn't follow. Can you show me an example? How can I pass the `latest_updated` time between `periods` (e.g. `today` vs `tomorrow`)?
@aoen there seems to be an issue with retries not executing. See also: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-695 . Will try to dive in but might need help
@bolkedebruin I will take a look hopefully today

@bolkedebruin I couldn't repro on that version albeit with the SequentialExecutor (the task retried successfully). I feel if there was a bug though it would be with the dagrun logic, not the task dependency logic (dagruns should not be getting set to failed when there is an up_for_retry task ).

Does that make sense to you?

Hey @robin-miller-ow thanks for extending on the APi functionality. Couple of things

- Please split your PR per functionality you are adding
- Also make sure if you update/add endpoints to make them available in api/clients/
- execution_date should not be passed in the URL but as part of the POST request
- this also removes the need for trigger_dag_for_date it can just be handled in the original function.

On Sun, Dec 18, 2016 at 12:44 PM, bolkedebruin <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> *@bolkedebruin* commented on this pull request.
> ------------------------------
>
> In airflow/bin/cli.py
> <https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/1934>:
>
> >          if not os.path.exists(directory):
>              # Create the directory as group writable using custom mkdirs
>              # as os.makedirs doesn't set mode properly.
>              mode = 0x775
> -            mkdirs(directory, 0o775)
> +            mkdirs(directory, 0o777)
>
> Does it need to have these broad permissions. World readable is something
> else than world writable/executable.
>
> I won't be able to run the code as is in our environment (not allowed). It
> will be caught by security monitoring right away.
>
> Maybe we should make this change dependent on making backfills use the
> scheduler (ie that fixes the subdagoperator)?

@poulainv I ran into this use case today for needing to manually trigger a DAG that has the `LatestOnlyOperator` in it. My workaround isn't very elegant, but you can trigger the DAG manually using the CLI. Then in the UI, go to the Tree View for the DAG, and then click on the `Skipped` task. You can the re-run the task manually using the **Run** button.

Hi @bolkedebruin, I have updated this branch to contain only the first change (allowing the passing of an execution_date to trigger_dag). To avoid merge complications, I have set up the other changes to each follow on from each other, so I'll open a PR for the next once this is merged in and then one after that.

So we do not have this must have feature because of a 2 seconds sleep in the test?
I have processes that are stuck and become ghost processes because the timeout / kill does not propagate...

@blrnw3 the fix (moving `clear_xcom_data()`) looks great to me. 

Are we sure that your first test is actually testing the right thing? Your comment says it won't clear because the other TI is running, but I think that TI has already ended and it's not clearing because of the `mark_success` flag. Maybe just a clarification.

Thanks @jlowin. I've clarified the comment.

It's a little tricky to test the exact situation I found, because it relies to some extent on a race condition. The test I wrote simulates that by ignoring dependencies and marking success, which I think is a valid test because that is also a potential real-world use case, and more-easily testable.
Ok, I think that's reasonable -- just wanted to double check. Once Travis clears I will merge. Thanks!
Looks like I just exposed a PR-Tool bug that added [AIRFLOW-1] to the commit title. I'll look in to why!
Oh, it's because the boilerplate PR template has [AIRFLOW-1] in it. Interesting.
ah my mistake ðŸ˜…
No worries. Thanks for the PR!
